abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Lessons from the project
            experience suggest the following. Improving the quality of
            basic education, requires strong, and sustained commitment
            from the top levels of the state administration, as well as
            substantial financial resources on a continuous basis.
            However, substantial efforts must be placed in the prior
            establishment of an institutional framework, in monitoring
            and evaluation systems, and in the evaluation of schools
            administration. Furthermore, decentralization of primary
            education to municipal levels, does not automatically
            promote better quality; a proactive monitoring performance
            by the state, of the municipal administrations, and schools
            is needed, as well as offering specially designed programs
            in support of the school system. Similarly, regular
            quantitative assessment of student learning is essential,
            both to evaluate educational policies, and for self
            evaluation of schools. In looking at in-service training, it
            is most useful when focused on pedagogical aspects, i.e.,
            integrating pedagogic training with subject matter training
            is most advisable. As for the development, and
            implementation of a good educational information system, it
            is essential to provide feedback to decision makers at all levels.
